segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 And thanks for all the help getting this set up.
Sorry for the inconvenience.
So techniques and tools for becoming an intelligence operator.
Just to clarify the title, this is not how to get into the military and do this or into
any particular agency.
This is really just a focus on over the last year what Trace Labs has done and learned
from all the different people doing intelligence for the organization and then how you can
apply it and use the techniques yourself.
So a little outline of what I'll be going over today or in this hour.
I always like to know when I go into a talk, what am I going to get out of this?
What's it going to look like for the next little bit?
This is what it is.
I'm not going to go through every bullet point there, but that's what you got to look forward
to.
A little bit about myself.
So I've been working in IT for about 20 years.
Most of that's been security.
I actually know what this is, and I have a whole box of them in my garage somewhere,
and I remember those days.
I started off with like a 14.4 modem.
Yeah, yeah.
Someone else remembers those days?
Yeah.
So it's been really interesting in the journey to see how much we've done in the world of
security since then, right?
We went from basically none to a lot and very sophisticated at this point, right?
So it's been really interesting to watch that progress.
So that's my day job.
I also am a volunteer in Quiklum Search and Rescue.
I've been doing that for about 10 years.
I focus on tracking and a few other disciplines in that area, and the reason why that's relevant
is because we're going to talk about open source intelligence and intelligence gathering,
and as a tracker, it's really similar.
So I'll be drawing those similarities as we progress through this presentation.
I'm also the founder of Trace Labs, so I'll talk about that a little bit.
But a lot of the material in this presentation is from what a lot of our members have done
over the last year, and if you'd like to contact me, that's my Twitter and my email address.
So the standard disclaimer, I'm very opinionated.
I say a lot of things, and they're all just my opinions.
They don't reflect any company or affiliation that I have now or will have in the future.
All right.
So what's Trace Labs?
Trace Labs was an idea I had over a year ago.
I have a lot of dumb ideas.
This one really seemed to take off.
It's a nonprofit organization that's designed to help locate missing persons.
Having spent 10 years in SAR, we search for a lot of missing persons, but a lot of people
we don't look for.
The assumption by the law enforcement is that those people are going to come home.
Statistically speaking, most people do.
I was really looking at the ones that don't, and that's what this is designed to help.
So we provide a modern, cost-effective, and transparent solution to what I see as a growing
problem.
We focus on crowdsourcing open source intelligence through large organized events.
So what we typically do is an OSINT CTF at a conference.
That was really our bread and butter over the last year.
We're now branching off to do these sort of events in schools.
So last month we were at South Wales University in England where we did an event, and we typically
look for eight real missing people within that locale, so within that community.
If we can't find them in the community, we just keep broadening that radius from city
to state or province to country until we locate those eight missing people.
And so those are real missing people.
It's not theoretical.
So what we offer is a non-theoretical type CTF, which is really attractive for a lot
of people.
So these are real people, real world people, and we have to be very careful how we proceed
with that.
We do a lot of different events.
We used to do one event a month.
Now it's multiple events per month.
We're doing two events in the same day coming up pretty soon.
We've done a lot of B-sides, DEF CON, SEC talks in Australia, both on-site and virtual.
We've got a bunch of big events coming up with Layer 8 in the U.S., B-sides Vegas, and
we're just going to announce next week a couple of really big events that we're doing
that just haven't come out yet, so stand by for that.
So it's growing.
The model came from an idea, and it's taken off, and this whole crowdsourcing, open-source
intelligence has really caught on, and we're going to talk about how to apply that in other
industries as well.
So a couple of questions I often get asked around who are you looking for, and I break
it down into three main categories.
People that are hiding, that don't want to be found, those are typically people that
want to start their life new, and you could say, well, Rob, why are you looking for those
people?
Why are you bugging them?
Well, usually it's because they want to get away from some obligations, so the police
want to talk to them.
That could be child support and things like that.
Also people that are being hidden, so that's human trafficking, and then people that don't
even know they're missing, so that's child abductions.
So those are sort of the three main areas we focus on.
We don't just look for anybody.
Law enforcement actually has to post on the Internet something to the effect of we're
seeking the public's support to find this person.
That's really our calling card and our invitation to go look for that person.
Our scope is really limited, and that's by design.
We don't want to interfere with any criminal investigations, so we do passive reconnaissance,
no interaction, no friending, no liking, no commenting, no swiping right.
We don't follow up with anybody.
We don't want to interfere at all.
All we do is collect intelligence, package it up really nice, and then give that to law
enforcement, and then we move on to the next event.
A lot of people ask us, well, how many people have you found?
Well, we do locate people, but we don't really track that because we don't get involved.
We just give the intelligence, and then we walk away and go to the next event.
So now I'm going to get into actual stuff, techniques.
The first thing I want to do is talk about your OPSEC, and when you're doing this sort
of work, that's the first thing I like to talk about because for us and for other people
in this industry, we're looking quite often at bad people, and bad people probably don't
get as excited as you do about what you're doing, especially if you're using that information
to provide to law enforcement.
So if you're getting into this, you kind of want to be very aware of that.
Are these people going to find out that you're doing this and then come burn your house down?
Right?
I mean, that's bad.
So I've heard a lot of stories where this has actually gone in a bad way, so it's really
important to think about that.
As you prepare to do your intelligence gathering, these are a list of basic questions that you
should ask.
I think there's a bunch more that you probably want to go through, but think about why am
I doing this in the first place?
Did my friend down the road ask me to check out somebody they're thinking about renting
their apartment to?
Or is this a formal engagement where they're expecting a written report that's going to
be organized very nicely that I'm getting paid for?
So you really need to get the scope of what you're doing.
What's the worst that could happen?
So I spoke about that a little bit, right?
I want to be very careful how you proceed.
How are you preserving your intel?
So there's a lot of great tools out there that I would highly recommend.
Hunchly is one of them, right?
Are you going to go to court with this information or are the police going to ask you for it?
How are you preserving that information?
How are you categorizing it?
What sort of data points are you looking for?
All of that's important.
How will your report be consumed?
So if you have a 100-page report and no executive summary, I don't think people are going to
read it.
So that's really important to think about.
You can have the greatest intelligence, but if it's not consumable, how great really is
it?
What are your objectives, right?
What do you want to get out of your operation?
And then that follows into what does done look like?
So a lot of people will spin their wheels and they'll collect a ton of information,
which is fine, I guess, if you've got lots of time.
But we're really looking at what are you trying to achieve here?
And then how long do you have?
Do you have a month, a week, a day?
That's really going to define what you're going to be able to produce.
And then who are you going to share it with?
What's that look like?
Is it going to go on a USB drive?
Can you email it?
So some of the questions you need to ask before you start.
Technical setup.
So this is just the basics.
Everybody will have a different view on this.
But these are some of the things that I would initially look at.
I prefer a VM that I can archive after each operation.
I use VirtualBox.
It's free, easy to set up.
If you've got a Mac, you might want to use Fusion or Parallels.
Your platform, a lot of us use Kali Linux.
That's what I would prefer.
A lot of people run Windows, too.
Set up your apps.
Get Multigo, Recon NG all set up, get it installed and configured.
Get that as part of your snapshot so you can just reuse it every time.
You don't have to worry about reconfiguring it each time.
Get your admin apps, of course, set up so you can do screenshots really easily.
Hunchly, I'm a big fan of that.
Get your plug-in set up as well.
This is something people overlook a lot.
And then get your account set up as well for your social media.
I don't use a lot of fake accounts, but if you're going to use those, you want to set
those up well in advance.
You can do things with LinkedIn.
So on LinkedIn, I have it set so you can't see when I look at your profile.
Of course, I can't see when you look at mine, but I don't care, so that's okay.
And then, of course, you want to set up your VPN.
So if you're doing reconnaissance with more of a risky area, VPN definitely recommended.
So this is kind of your base.
Once you've got it set up, it's reusable.
So it's a little bit of work up front, but down the road, it's really going to save you
a lot of headaches.
So then you start to get into target acquisition, and this is really going to depend on what
type of target you have.
But some of these you can apply across the board.
So one of the things you want to start thinking about right away is unique identifiers.
How am I going to identify this target?
In SAR, we call them subjects.
So as a tracker, what I would be looking at is stuff about their feet.
So what kind of shoe size do they have?
What's their tread look like?
For you, you probably want to look at maybe name, phone number, email address, anything
like that that's going to allow me to identify that person, company, or whatever that target is.
Surprisingly enough, most of the information I get is usually not spelled correctly.
So if you don't check that, you start off down the road, and it's like, yeah, that's
actually not the person because the I was supposed to be an E. Very irritating.
Friends or family.
So if I need a little information on that, that's going to get me started a little bit
faster.
Special circumstance or situation.
So why am I looking for this person?
I say person because usually for us in Trace Labs, it is a person.
But it could be a company.
So what's triggered this investigation?
Is it an insurance fraud?
Is it a criminal activity investigation?
Why am I doing this?
The details around that is going to help you.
Stationary or mobile.
So is this person on the move a lot, or do they just kind of reside in that town?
That's going to help me select what tools I want to use.
And of course, lifestyle.
So if they're doing drugs, or if they're a criminal, or even clubs, anything like that's
going to help me as well.
That's going to narrow my scope.
Geography and mobility.
So do they reside in a certain area, or highly mobile as well?
That's going to change things.
Description.
Anything like that.
The part that stands out here are scars, tattoos, piercing.
Those are really helpful, because when I'm doing image analysis, or facial rec, or something
like that, a lot of times you'll get the person with the same name.
The picture looks really similar.
So it's like, yeah, that's the guy, or that's the girl.
And it's not.
So if I can pick out something very unique, like a piercing, or anything like that, that's
going to help a lot.
Sophistication level.
That's something I always want to be aware of.
Are they going to know you're looking for them?
And if so, what's that going to look like?
Are they aware of the situation?
What's your risk level?
So are they going to set up things to be able to alert them that you're looking?
Are they going to be able to hide very easily?
That sort of stuff.
So those are sort of the things I work through.
We see our members work through that sort of stuff.
Usually there are members that come into Trace Labs.
They're typically, some of them are very new to OSINT and intelligence gathering, so they
get stuck fairly quickly.
These are some of the things I talk to them about to keep them going.
Instead of looking at your target, look at things that are peripheral around your target.
In tracking, we do that too.
We don't look for the subject.
We look for what we call sign.
So friends and family are perfect.
For missing people, we get a lot of chatter around the activity.
So that's great.
So you'll look for those social butterflies that are producing the most amount of content,
and that'll usually take us down a path.
Online accounts are really good to look at, because not because they're their accounts,
but I look for the patterns, things like usernames, what kind of platforms they prefer as far
as social media, that sort of stuff.
Criminal records, I don't know if those are publicly available here.
In Canada, I can find your criminal record, and I really like those, because it'll show
me not only what kind of crimes you've committed, but also your aliases that you like to use.
And those are usually linked to social media accounts, and that makes my job so much easier
to find those.
School records and photos, so if I can find a photo of you anywhere, that's going to be
a bonus.
I can use a bunch of apps to help me find you that way.
Past employees and employers, usually on employee websites or employer websites, rather, sometimes
there's pictures and profiles of people.
That's golden.
Sports teams, either you're playing or maybe you're betting on them.
Team memberships, fantastic as well.
Anywhere that you could leave a trace as far as on a forum, so Amazon accounts are very
popular.
Strava, so we all have these watches, a lot of us do anyway, right, that's uploading content
to the internet.
A lot of those were very open, only recently they became a little more private.
Any sort of video games, so if I detect you, especially if you're a younger person and
you're playing video games, I can get on Steam or any other sort of forum where I see you
might have posted.
Trip advisor, if you're a traveler and you like to review stuff, I'm going to look there
as well.
So, those are some different areas you can look to pick up information.
So I'll start with real names.
Quite often that's what you're given, somebody's name, maybe a company name as well.
It's the most common starting point.
Again, make sure it's spelled correctly.
Are they using the middle name in their usernames, do they like to use that, or the initial,
you know.
Start off, just do some Google dorking, LinkedIn.
I love LinkedIn and it sounds ridiculously simple, but LinkedIn is so nice because it
gives you a nice structure, right?
If you send me a LinkedIn request, I will accept no matter what, because it just widens
my scope of search, and especially for a company, you can go in there and you can find the structure,
you can find who reports to who, how involved they are in the industry, and usually you
can find out more social media accounts as well.
So, I really like using that to start off with some of my searches.
You want to begin building a profile once you get this initial information.
Family, friends, employment, residence, those are kind of my go-to areas, and those will
take you off into different areas depending on what you find.
Ultimately, I want to work towards getting those kind of four main areas, real name,
email addresses, usernames, and of course, as many pictures as I can find as well.
Depending on the occupation of the person, you're going to be able to go to certain sites.
Most of us here are in security or IT.
This is an example of a site I'd go to if I have your real name to see if you've registered
any domains.
Online registration is great.
It's actually more private now.
They're starting to hide a lot of that information, but it used to reveal a ton of stuff like
your phone number, your email address, and stuff like that, which was fantastic.
So LinkedIn, I just can't get enough of LinkedIn.
It's just such a fantastic tool for this sort of work.
They try to make you pay for the service to get more details.
LinkedIn X-Ray is a great tool that you can use to get past that and get great searches.
It really takes the limitations off of it.
If you have their email address, you can just plug it into that URL there and get their
profile right away, which makes things a little faster.
So if you have their username, you can usually guess that by firstname.lastname.
If that doesn't work, you try to get their email address, and that'll usually have their
username in it, and they'll usually reuse that across platforms.
Just like password reuse, you'll see username reuse quite a bit.
So we want to see if they've used their middle name or not.
Is this a unique alias, or are they reusing that alias quite a bit?
Is it already existing?
Do they have a number in it?
So quite often with a company, they'll add a number to the end of their username if there's
already a person in that company that has that name.
And is it consistent across their personal and their work?
So if it is, that's much easier as well if you have their work email or username.
So some of the sites that I like to use to check usernames, there's a couple of them
here.
You can plug it in.
And these sites are pretty similar how they work.
It'll show you if that username's used across those different social media accounts.
And it does dozens and dozens of different social media platforms.
So it's really nice and quick.
Actually a lot of these sites, you can click on it, and it'll actually show you not only
if it's in use or not, but also give you information about that username.
So for a really quick check, it's well worth it.
I use all three because they're all slightly different.
If that doesn't work, just manually check these top four social media platforms.
I like YouTube.
It's kind of the forgotten child quite often.
But YouTube's given me some of the best results.
And in our TraceLabs operations, I see a lot of people score really well with that as well.
For email, so email's tricky.
I like to make sure that it is actually owned by the target.
Quite often we see people make mistakes with that where they just assume it is because
it's the same name.
But often it's not.
So there's a lot of email verification services out there that you can use.
These are the top three that I use that will actually validate if it's real to start off
with.
And then it'll also tell you quite often information about the user.
So it might give you the person's name, even phone number, things like that, which is really
handy and moves you to the next level.
The third from the bottom there will actually browse the entire domain.
So it won't give you every email in the domain, but it'll give you a bunch of them, which
is nice, because then you can correlate that with their friends and family or other people
that might be in that company.
Of course, Bing and Google, that should be at the top of the list, actually, because
I like to do that quite often.
Just that, if you've got their email address, will usually score you some good information.
Now this is my favorite part with email.
I love to go to these breached data search engines, because I just take their email,
plug it in there, and it's going to tell me all these other platforms that they're using
that have been breached.
So just the fact that they're using those other platforms is really nice to know.
If you were a bad guy, you could download that breached data, and then you'd probably
have their password if they haven't changed it.
I'm not recommending you do that, but bad guys could.
And I use all of them, because they're all slightly different.
You'll see a lot of overlap, again, with those, but they're all slightly different.
Gravatar Service, so a lot of people used to use this.
Not so much anymore, but that usually will give you a little bit of information as well.
And then if they've registered any sort of DNS stuff, which most of us in this room have,
you can go to that URL and get their more information.
Ashley Madison, so of course that's just like the breached data one.
I was thinking about this earlier.
If this is breached data and people's email address is in there and you find it, I mean,
that's really bad, right?
So there's high risk for these sort of things.
All these sites are going to get breached sooner or later, right?
So if it's something like Ashley Madison, there's huge potential there to get in a lot
of trouble quickly, right?
I mean, you could sign up all your friends for something like that, because you know
it's going to get breached later, right?
Imagine those conversations with their spouse or partner later on, right?
So really, really bad stuff.
So I spelt LinkedIn wrong, I just noticed.
That's supposed to be LinkedIn.
So that's an example of what you'll see for me.
And some people will have even more.
They'll have their websites, which I love, public websites, or their personal websites
that'll show you lots of great information.
It's my favorite just to get the ball rolling to start with.
These are really popular sites to use for people to get more information on an individual.
Very popular in the U.S., very U.S.-centric.
You probably have versions of this here.
I live in Canada, that's where I reside, so for me, if I'm looking up somebody in Canada,
they don't work as good, they still do have some information.
I usually blast through these when I'm looking for somebody.
Pitbull usually gives me the best results.
It takes two seconds to do, so I recommend trying these out if you want information on
somebody.
Quite often it'll give me their home address, sometimes their phone number, maybe their
cell phone number, and information about their family, which is then something I can
use as well.
So mileage will vary depending on what part of the country or world you're in.
Snapchat.
So I'm not a huge Snapchat advocate for OSINT.
It's pretty cool, because it does some neat things, and there's some interesting tools
out there.
I'm a huge fan of geolocation for OSINT, because usually an operation consists of a certain
scope.
You have a certain place, a certain time, a certain target.
There's a bunch of tools out there for this app, so if they're using Snapchat, there's
a tool here to search by username, so if you've got a username, you can find them pretty quickly,
which is nice.
And then there's this map search content app here, which is cool, and you can't really
see it, but there's these blue dots or blue circles on there, near the top, right above
where it says Coquitlam, there's one.
So you can click on there, and you can see what's going on, it's someone's Snapchat in
that location at a certain time.
So that's nice if you're looking for location and time, and they're using Snapchat.
Then we get into geolocation, so I really like using these sort of tools.
EchoSec is very popular with the agencies in Canada, most of the law enforcement teams
use this, and it's good, I really like it.
I tend to use ArcGIS, there's a free demo you can get.
You can actually use the free demo of EchoSec, although it's a little bit limited in its
functionality.
ArcGIS, I think you get the full version for 30 days.
The reason that I really like this is because I basically start off, I map out on the map,
it's like a Google Maps interface, the location that I want to look at, then I pick the social
media channels that I want, Twitter, Facebook, all the usuals, right, and then the time frame
that I'm looking for.
So if you know the person's in that vicinity at that time, it's really nice.
Or they're friends, or if there's any sort of activity.
ArcGIS is used for emergency management, so if there's an earthquake or some other
big bad event, you can use it for that.
So it works great for our purposes, it's just not built for our industry, so a lot of people
don't know about it.
So I also like to go back and use some of these tools, because I find quite often people
that want to erase their trace on the internet will do that, and the people that are really
good at it will do it months in advance.
So we've had several cases of people disappearing, and they deleted a lot of their accounts,
but you can go back in time, of course, with some of these tools, and kind of take a look
at what it looked like before.
It's really hard to erase yourself off the internet.
So this seems really simple, but it's really effective as well.
So just a few more notes on going back in time and looking at history of a place.
I use this a lot, I'm a huge fan of Google Street View, typically when I'm doing reconnaissance
on a structure, I'll first look at Google Maps, I'll look at the perimeter, I'll look
at the top of the building to see what they've got there, I'll look for loading docks, look
for entry from the roof, look at what's on the roof, go through all of that.
Street View is really cool as well, I use it all the time, and one of the things I like
about it is the history that it keeps, right?
So not only am I looking at this, this is a cigar shop in Paris, if anybody was wondering,
and it shows me what it looks like from the outside, there's parking, there's a single
door on the front, stuff like that, and you can see the Street View in the top left corner
there and it's showing me, well, there's other pictures I can look at from other time periods.
So if I go back in time, now I can see this is more in the evening, there's no parking
there, the bus stop is gone, look at the garbage cans, so if I'm going to do a physical pen
testing later, this is my reconnaissance mode, I'm taking a look at this, oh, they've got
the steel doors that close at night, okay, so that's interesting, but for me, I like
the garbage bins because then I can pose as the garbage person, I know the company name,
I know that they're probably not shredding, it looks like they're just dumping stuff in
there, so there's a bunch of things like that that I'll look at, and this is really simple,
but there's, every company that I look at, there's always stuff like this that I'll pick
out from going back in time like that.
So if your target is mobile, this is actually getting to be more and more the case, I'll
give you an example of this, it's ironic, but I came here, I flew here from Canada,
I took, oh, what's the German airline, Lufthansa, right, so I flew with them, and I was actually,
somebody mentioned earlier, they saw my tweet, I was waiting in line, and I get frustrated
really easily, and then of course I start tweeting, and so I tweeted something to them,
I was like, oh, I'm waiting in line for like five minutes here, and I put a picture of
the people in line, and then today I got an email, a great phishing attempt from them,
apparently, you know, so it was very timely, so someone obviously was monitoring that,
just brilliant, right, so that's an example of where people are monitoring my travel activity,
and then responding to that, so the bad guys were really smart in that case, cause I looked
at it, and I almost clicked it, cause it looked so good, and it was just perfectly timed,
so these are some of the things I would look at, Tripcase, very popular mobile app, Uber,
a little bit harder to get information from these, but there's other ones that have more
of kind of a forum-based environment, right, Airbnb, everybody leaves their reviews on
there, if you've got their username, you could probably find some of their stuff there, everybody's
got Travel Points, that's another great area to take a look at, and then memberships, rental
car stuff, these forums, like Trip Planner, Booking.com, Expedia, Priceline, right, a
lot of people are very active in those, I bet you most of this room has at least posted
something once in one of these forums, right, so that can tell me a little bit about your
travel habits, where you like to travel, all that sort of stuff, let me get into physical
infrastructure a little bit, so usually I kind of start there, even if it's a person
I'm looking for, I want to look at where they reside and where they work, and I want to
look at some of these things, if I'm doing reconnaissance on a company, of course this
is even more important, I love finding the YouTube videos of the tour of the office,
because that basically gives me everything I need to know all at once, I just go frame
by frame, I look at their Wi-Fi, I look at their CCTV, I look at their door access, I
look at all those things, it's great.
Commercial property information, so are they leasing, and if so, that's going to usually
give me the whole floor plan, which is really handy, especially if you're going to do physical
pen testing and try to walk right in the door.
Street view, so I talked about that, huge fan of that, and then there's all this other
stuff as well, right, so all the associated records that they're going to have with City
Hall, legal records, fire up Shodan, see what their IoT looks like, lots of opportunities
there, I also like to get into their parking, their security, food delivery, there's lots
of opportunities there as well, so tons of stuff, I could talk for probably an hour just
on that.
Technical infrastructure, so this is probably, most of you are already pretty familiar with
a lot of these sites and tools, some of the ones that I really like is Hurricane Electric,
you know, there's a lot more out there now, but that's been my go-to site for ages.
Some of this is a little bit more private now, as far as domain registration and stuff
like that, but there's still tons of information out there, people really don't think about
this, and they forget about it, and it sits there for years, so it's usually I can find
your name, your email address, your phone number, and that's great.
Sometimes it's a DL, so I can get that as well, wiggle.net is one of my favorites, it's
